rev.comment: wikipedia is not a place for rumors, lets just wait until it is leaked onto the internet or some site reports that
rev.diff:
Line 95: Line 95:
On February 8, 2009, build 7022 x86 of Windows 7 was leaked to file sharing sites on the Internet by a Microsoft Ukraine employee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neowin.net/news/main/09/02/08/windows-7-build-7022-leaks|title=Windows 7 build 7022 leaks|publisher=Neowin|author=Tom Warren}}</ref>. On March 1, 2009, build 7022 x64 was leaked. Reviewers have noted that [[Internet Explorer 8]] has been updated to RC1, a few new icons, new animation effects for Windows Sidebar which is now the Windows Desktop Gallery with new icons and changes to Paint and a faster setup process. The build was completed on January 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/02/whats-new-in-the-leaked-windows-7-build-7022.ars|title=What's new in the leaked Windows 7 build 7022|publisher=Ars Technica|author=Emil Protalinski}}</ref>
On February 8, 2009, build 7022 x86 of Windows 7 was leaked to file sharing sites on the Internet by a Microsoft Ukraine employee<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neowin.net/news/main/09/02/08/windows-7-build-7022-leaks|title=Windows 7 build 7022 leaks|publisher=Neowin|author=Tom Warren}}</ref>. On March 1, 2009, build 7022 x64 was leaked. Reviewers have noted that [[Internet Explorer 8]] has been updated to RC1, a few new icons, new animation effects for Windows Sidebar which is now the Windows Desktop Gallery with new icons and changes to Paint and a faster setup process. The build was completed on January 15, 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/02/whats-new-in-the-leaked-windows-7-build-7022.ars|title=What's new in the leaked Windows 7 build 7022|publisher=Ars Technica|author=Emil Protalinski}}</ref>
â
A 64-bit build 7048 was leaked on March 2, 2009<ref>{{cite web | url = http://windows7center.com/windows-7-news/windows-7-build-7048-x64-download-leaked/ | title = Windows 7 Build 7048 x64 Download Leaked - Windows 7 Center}}</ref> and the 32-bit build 7048 was leaked on the March 6. One notable change of this build is that users now have the ability to turn off functionality of various Windows features, like Internet Explorer, Windows Search, and Windows Media Player via the Control Panel. Ars Technica did a roundup of some of the visual UI changes between build 7000 and 7048 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/03/side-by-side-changes-from-windows-7-beta-to-build-7048.ars/|title=Side by side: UI changes from Windows 7 beta to build 7048|publisher=Ars Technica|author=Emil Protalinski}}</ref> and ZDNet managed to do some performance tests showing build 7048 is superior to build 7000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/hardware/?p=3789|title=Windows 7 build 7048 vs. Windows 7 beta 1 vs. Vista vs. XP performance shootout - which is best?|publisher=ZDNet|author=Adrian Kingsley-Hughes}}</ref>. A screenshot of the setup file properties for build 7062 was leaked to the internet on the March 8, 2009. The file explains that it was compiled on March 7, 2009 at 12:45 PM. It is not yet known if this screenshot is fake or not. On March 11, 2009, build 7057 x86 was leaked.<ref>http://hacktolive.org/blog/2009/download-windows-7-build-7057-32-bits/ Windows 7 build 7057 x86</ref> The build was compiled on March 5, 2009. <ref>{{cite web | url = http://windows7center.com/windows-7-news/windows-7-build-7057-x86-32-bit-download-leaked/ | title = Windows 7 Build 7057 x86 Download Leaked - Windows 7 Center}}</ref> Build 7057 x64 also leaked to the Internet on March 13, 2009<ref>http://hacktolive.org/blog/2009/download-windows-7-build-7057-64-bits-x64/ Windows 7 build 7057 x64</ref>. Rumours have surfaced about build 7065. It is unknown if these rumour are true.
+
A 64-bit build 7048 was leaked on March 2, 2009<ref>{{cite web | url = http://windows7center.com/windows-7-news/windows-7-build-7048-x64-download-leaked/ | title = Windows 7 Build 7048 x64 Download Leaked - Windows 7 Center}}</ref> and the 32-bit build 7048 was leaked on the March 6. One notable change of this build is that users now have the ability to turn off functionality of various Windows features, like Internet Explorer, Windows Search, and Windows Media Player via the Control Panel. Ars Technica did a roundup of some of the visual UI changes between build 7000 and 7048 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://arstechnica.com/microsoft/news/2009/03/side-by-side-changes-from-windows-7-beta-to-build-7048.ars/|title=Side by side: UI changes from Windows 7 beta to build 7048|publisher=Ars Technica|author=Emil Protalinski}}</ref> and ZDNet managed to do some performance tests showing build 7048 is superior to build 7000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.zdnet.com/hardware/?p=3789|title=Windows 7 build 7048 vs. Windows 7 beta 1 vs. Vista vs. XP performance shootout - which is best?|publisher=ZDNet|author=Adrian Kingsley-Hughes}}</ref>. A screenshot of the setup file properties for build 7062 was leaked to the internet on the March 8, 2009. The file explains that it was compiled on March 7, 2009 at 12:45 PM. It is not yet known if this screenshot is fake or not. On March 11, 2009, build 7057 x86 was leaked.<ref>http://hacktolive.org/blog/2009/download-windows-7-build-7057-32-bits/ Windows 7 build 7057 x86</ref> The build was compiled on March 5, 2009. <ref>{{cite web | url = http://windows7center.com/windows-7-news/windows-7-build-7057-x86-32-bit-download-leaked/ | title = Windows 7 Build 7057 x86 Download Leaked - Windows 7 Center}}</ref> Build 7057 x64 also leaked to the Internet on March 13, 2009<ref>http://hacktolive.org/blog/2009/download-windows-7-build-7057-64-bits-x64/ Windows 7 build 7057 x64</ref>.
